title: Psalms Chapter 31 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 31 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 31 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 31.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:1, where does David say he puts his trust?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:1 says, 'In thee, O LORD, do I put my trust; let me never be ashamed.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:2, what does David ask the LORD to be for him?
options: A strong rock and house of defence
questions.correctAnswer: A strong rock and house of defence
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:2 says, 'be thou my strong rock, for an house of defence to save me.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 31:3 describes God as David's rock and fortress.
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:3 states, 'For thou art my rock and my fortress.'

questions.question: What does David ask God to pull him out of in Psalms 31:4?
options: The net that they have laid privily for me
questions.correctAnswer: The net that they have laid privily for me
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:4 says, 'Pull me out of the net that they have laid privily for me.'

questions.question: In Psalms 31:5, to whose hand does David commit his spirit?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:5 states, 'Into thine hand I commit my spirit.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 31:6: 'I have hated them that regard lying ______.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:6 says, 'I have hated them that regard lying vanities.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:7, why will David be glad and rejoice?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:7 states, 'I will be glad and rejoice in thy mercy.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 31:8 says the LORD shut David up into the hand of the enemy.
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:8 says, 'And hast not shut me up into the hand of the enemy.'

questions.question: What is consumed from grief according to Psalms 31:9?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:9 says, 'mine eye is consumed with grief.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:10, what causes David's strength to fail?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:10 states, 'my strength faileth because of mine iniquity.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 31:11: 'I was a reproach among all mine enemies, but especially among my ______.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:11 says, 'but especially among my neighbours.'

questions.question: What do David's enemies devise according to Psalms 31:13?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:13 says they 'devised to take away my life.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:14, whom does David say he trusted?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:14 says, 'But I trusted in thee, O LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 31:15 says David's times are in his own hand.
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:15 states, 'My times are in thy hand.'

questions.question: What does David ask God to make shine upon him in Psalms 31:16?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:16 says, 'Make thy face to shine upon thy servant.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 31 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 31 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 31, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during adversity?
options: Trust in the LORD and commit your spirit to Him for deliverance
Rely on your own strength and wisdom to overcome troubles
Avoid prayer and wait for problems to fade away
Focus on human help rather than God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD and commit your spirit to Him for deliverance
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:1-5 encourages trusting God as a strong rock and committing one’s spirit to Him. Verses 5, 14, and 15 highlight trusting in God’s guidance and protection during difficult times.

questions.question: How does Psalms 31 describe God's role in protecting those who put their trust in Him?
options: God is a rock, fortress, and a strong house of defense
God is distant and indifferent to human troubles
God only watches but does not intervene
God punishes believers for their struggles
questions.correctAnswer: God is a rock, fortress, and a strong house of defense
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 describe God as a strong rock and fortress, providing refuge and protection for those who trust Him.

questions.question: When facing slander and opposition, what attitude does Psalms 31 recommend?
options: Trust in the LORD and declare Him as your God
Retaliate with harsh words and anger
Ignore God and rely on your own plans
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD and declare Him as your God
questions.explanation: Verse 14 shows David’s trust in the LORD amid plots against him. This teaches believers to respond to opposition with faith and reliance on God.

questions.question: What does Psalms 31 teach about prayer in times of distress?
options: Call upon the LORD with confidence and seek His mercy
Avoid prayer because God does not listen
questions.correctAnswer: Call upon the LORD with confidence and seek His mercy
questions.explanation: Verses 9, 16, and 22 reveal David’s earnest prayers for mercy and deliverance, showing the importance of persistent and confident prayer.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by grief and weakness. What practical encouragement does Psalms 31 offer?
options: God knows your soul in adversities and will strengthen your heart
You must overcome grief on your own
Hide your feelings and avoid community
questions.correctAnswer: God knows your soul in adversities and will strengthen your heart
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 24 affirm God’s knowledge of our troubles and promise to strengthen those who hope in Him.

questions.question: According to Psalms 31, how should believers respond to those who speak lies and slander against the righteous?
options: Trust God to silence the lying lips and bring justice
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to silence the lying lips and bring justice
questions.explanation: Verse 18 prays for God to silence those who speak grievous and proud lies, teaching believers to rely on God's justice rather than personal retaliation.

questions.question: Which biblical virtue does Psalms 31 highlight when David says, 'I have hated them that regard lying vanities'?
questions.explanation: Verse 6 emphasizes hatred toward falsehood and vanities, encouraging believers to value honesty and integrity in daily life.

questions.question: What does Psalms 31 teach about God’s reward for the faithful and the proud doer?
options: The LORD preserves the faithful and punishes the proud doer
The LORD rewards both the faithful and the proud equally
The proud doer is rewarded more than the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD preserves the faithful and punishes the proud doer
questions.explanation: Verse 23 states that the LORD preserves the faithful and plentifully rewards the proud doer with punishment, teaching accountability and faithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 31 encourages believers to be courageous and hopeful because God strengthens their hearts.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 urges believers to be of good courage and promises that God will strengthen the heart of those who hope in Him.

questions.question: How does Psalms 31 describe God’s kindness toward those who trust Him?
options: God’s goodness is great and shown marvelously like a strong city
God’s kindness is minimal and unreliable
God’s kindness depends on human merit
God hides His goodness from believers
questions.correctAnswer: God’s goodness is great and shown marvelously like a strong city
questions.explanation: Verse 21 praises God’s marvelous kindness, describing it as a strong city protecting the believer, illustrating God’s powerful and faithful care.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'My times are in thy hand: deliver me from the hand of mine enemies, and from them that ______ me.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:15 shows David committing his times into God's hands and seeking deliverance from enemies and persecutors.

questions.question: What practical lesson for perseverance through trials can be drawn from David’s experience in Psalms 31?
options: Trust God even when feeling forgotten and weak
Give up when enemies reproach you
Avoid others and isolate yourself completely
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God even when feeling forgotten and weak
questions.explanation: Verses 11 and 12 describe feelings of reproach and being forgotten, yet the overall passage encourages trust in God despite such hardships.

questions.question: What does Psalms 31 say about the protection God provides against human pride and gossip?
options: God hides the faithful in His presence and protects them from strife
God leaves believers exposed to gossip
God encourages believers to engage in gossip
God punishes believers for avoiding conflict
questions.correctAnswer: God hides the faithful in His presence and protects them from strife
questions.explanation: Verse 20 states God hides the faithful in the secret of His presence, protecting them from the pride of man and strife of tongues.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 31, God hears the voice of those who cry out to Him even when they feel cut off.
questions.explanation: Verse 22 affirms that though David felt cut off, God still heard his supplications when he cried out.

questions.question: How does Psalms 31 guide believers to respond when they have been wronged or persecuted?
options: Call on the LORD to deliver and cause the wicked to be ashamed
questions.correctAnswer: Call on the LORD to deliver and cause the wicked to be ashamed
questions.explanation: Verses 17 and 18 encourage calling upon God for deliverance and letting the wicked be ashamed and silent, teaching believers to trust God for justice.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 31 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 31.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:1, the psalmist asks the LORD to let him never be what?
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states, 'let me never be ashamed,' highlighting the psalmist's plea for vindication and honor.

questions.question: Which metaphor is used in Psalms 31:2 to describe God as a place of safety?
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls God 'my strong rock, for an house of defence,' a common ancient Near Eastern symbol for protection and refuge.

questions.question: What does the psalmist commit into God's hand in Psalms 31:5, a phrase also echoed by Jesus on the cross?
questions.explanation: 'Into thine hand I commit my spirit' is a profound expression of trust and surrender, paralleled in Luke 23:46 by Jesus.

questions.question: Psalms 31:6 shows a contrast between the psalmist's feelings towards lying vanities and in whom he trusts. Who is the object of his trust?
questions.explanation: The psalmist explicitly states, 'but I trust in the LORD,' showing reliance on God contrasted with hatred of falsehood.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Psalms 31:7 where the psalmist expresses gladness and rejoicing in God's mercy?
questions.explanation: The verse juxtaposes gladness and rejoicing with mercy and consideration, exhibiting synonymous parallelism typical of Hebrew poetry.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:8, what does the LORD set the psalmist's feet in, symbolizing freedom and safety?
questions.explanation: Being set in 'a large room' metaphorically expresses spaciousness and deliverance from confinement or danger.

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 31:11, the psalmist describes himself as a figure of reproach and fear even among his neighbors and acquaintances.
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'I was a reproach among all mine enemies... they that did see me without fled from me,' confirming this social alienation.

questions.question: What image in Psalms 31:12 symbolizes the psalmist's sense of being broken and forgotten?
questions.explanation: The psalmist says, 'I am like a broken vessel,' a metaphor for fragility and abandonment in ancient Israelite culture.

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:13, what do the enemies devise against the psalmist?
questions.explanation: The verse records their counsel 'to take away my life,' indicating a mortal threat.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:15, the psalmist declares that his times are in whose hand?
questions.explanation: The verse reads, 'My times are in thy hand,' signifying divine sovereignty over life and circumstances.

questions.question: What request does the psalmist make in Psalms 31:16 regarding God's face?
options: Make thy face to shine upon thy servant
questions.correctAnswer: Make thy face to shine upon thy servant
questions.explanation: The psalmist petitions for God's favorable presence: 'Make thy face to shine upon thy servant.'

questions.question: What theme is developed in Psalms 31:17-18 concerning the wicked and lying lips?
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls for the wicked to be ashamed and for lying lips to be silenced, emphasizing divine justice.

questions.question: Psalms 31:19 speaks of God's goodness laid up for whom?
questions.explanation: The verse praises God's goodness reserved for those who fear Him, a key Old Testament motif.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:20, God is described as hiding the faithful in what kind of place?
questions.explanation: This phrase denotes intimate divine protection from human arrogance and conflict.

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:24, what is the promised result for those who hope in the LORD?
questions.explanation: The verse encourages courage by affirming God's strengthening of the hopeful heart.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 31 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 31 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:1, in whom does the psalmist place his trust, and what does he request from God?
options: In the LORD; to never be ashamed and to be delivered in righteousness
In his own strength; to conquer his enemies
In the king; to grant him victory
In the temple; to find refuge
questions.correctAnswer: In the LORD; to never be ashamed and to be delivered in righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:1 states, 'In thee, O LORD, do I put my trust; let me never be ashamed: deliver me in thy righteousness.' The psalmist trusts God alone for deliverance and vindication, consistent with Proverbs 3:5, Isaiah 26:3, Romans 15:13, and 2 Timothy 1:12, which affirm trust in God as the foundation of hope and righteousness.

questions.question: What metaphor does the psalmist use in Psalms 31:2 to describe God’s protective role?
options: Strong rock and house of defence
questions.correctAnswer: Strong rock and house of defence
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:2 describes God as a 'strong rock' and 'house of defence,' emphasizing His strength and security. Similar imagery appears in 2 Samuel 22:2-3, Psalm 18:2, Isaiah 26:4, and Hebrews 6:18, showing God's reliability as a refuge.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:5, what does the psalmist commit into God's hand, and what is God identified as?
options: His spirit; LORD God of truth
questions.correctAnswer: His spirit; LORD God of truth
questions.explanation: The psalmist says, 'Into thine hand I commit my spirit: thou hast redeemed me, O LORD God of truth' (Psalms 31:5). This reflects trust in God’s faithfulness, resonating with Jesus' words in Luke 23:46, God’s redemption in Psalm 34:22, faithfulness in Deuteronomy 32:4, and the Spirit’s role in 2 Timothy 1:12.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his attitude toward those who regard lying vanities in Psalms 31:6?
options: He hates them but trusts in the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He hates them but trusts in the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:6 says, 'I have hated them that regard lying vanities: but I trust in the LORD.' This expresses the rejection of falsehood and idolatry, consistent with Psalm 119:163, Proverbs 6:16-19, Isaiah 59:15, and John 14:1, which emphasize faithfulness and truth in God over deceit.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s response to God’s mercy as expressed in Psalms 31:7?
options: He will be glad and rejoice
questions.correctAnswer: He will be glad and rejoice
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:7 states, 'I will be glad and rejoice in thy mercy,' indicating joy and gratitude for God’s compassion. This aligns with Psalm 103:8, Lamentations 3:22-23, Romans 12:12, and 1 Peter 1:3, which portray mercy as a cause for rejoicing and hope.

questions.question: What does the psalmist describe about his enemies and his social standing in Psalms 31:11?
options: He was a reproach and a fear; even neighbors fled
He was honored and respected by all
He was victorious over all enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He was a reproach and a fear; even neighbors fled
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:11 describes the psalmist as 'a reproach among all mine enemies...they that did see me without fled from me.' This reflects the social alienation caused by suffering, paralleling Psalm 69:7-8, Job 30:9-10, Isaiah 53:3, and John 15:18-20 where the righteous suffer rejection.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 31:15 reveals the psalmist’s view of divine sovereignty over life events?
options: My times are in thy hand
Deliver me from the hand of mine enemies
I am forgotten as a dead man
questions.correctAnswer: My times are in thy hand
questions.explanation: The phrase 'My times are in thy hand' (Psalms 31:15) affirms God's sovereign control over the believer’s life and circumstances. This echoes Job 12:10, Ecclesiastes 3:1, Acts 17:26, and Hebrews 9:27, affirming God’s providence and timing.

questions.question: What does Psalms 31:16 ask God to do for His servant, and why?
options: Make thy face to shine; save for thy mercies' sake
Send an angel; to defeat enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Make thy face to shine; save for thy mercies' sake
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:16 requests God to 'Make thy face to shine upon thy servant: save me for thy mercies' sake,' symbolizing favor and salvation. This is consistent with Numbers 6:25-26, Psalm 4:6, 2 Corinthians 4:6, and Ephesians 2:4-5, illustrating God’s grace and saving mercy.

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:17-18, who does the psalmist ask to be put to shame and silenced?
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:17-18 prays that 'the wicked be ashamed' and 'the lying lips be put to silence,' condemning those who oppose the righteous. This theme is echoed in Psalm 109:2, Proverbs 10:18, Isaiah 57:21, and Matthew 5:11-12, which call for divine justice upon evildoers.

questions.question: What blessing does the psalmist attribute to those who fear and trust in God in Psalms 31:19?
options: Great goodness laid up and wrought before men
questions.correctAnswer: Great goodness laid up and wrought before men
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:19 celebrates 'how great is thy goodness...for them that fear thee...that trust in thee,' highlighting God’s blessings and favor publicly displayed. This aligns with Psalm 34:8, Proverbs 3:5-6, Romans 8:28, and James 1:12, affirming God’s reward for faithfulness.

questions.question: In Psalms 31:20, where does God hide and protect those who fear Him?
options: In the secret of thy presence and a pavilion
questions.correctAnswer: In the secret of thy presence and a pavilion
questions.explanation: The psalmist says God 'shalt hide them in the secret of thy presence...in a pavilion' (Psalms 31:20), signifying intimate, protective fellowship. Similar protection is found in Psalm 27:5, Isaiah 25:4, John 10:27-28, and Revelation 7:15, emphasizing God’s shelter over His people.

questions.question: What does Psalms 31:21 credit the LORD with showing to the psalmist?
options: His marvellous kindness in a strong city
questions.correctAnswer: His marvellous kindness in a strong city
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:21 praises God for His 'marvellous kindness in a strong city,' symbolizing divine protection and favor. This motif is found in Psalm 18:46, Nehemiah 2:17, Isaiah 41:10, and Acts 18:10, illustrating God’s sustaining kindness amid adversity.

questions.question: What does the psalmist confess in haste in Psalms 31:22, and how does God respond?
options: He thought he was cut off; God heard his supplications
He doubted his salvation; God punished him
He trusted in man; God corrected him
He sought revenge; God forgave him
questions.correctAnswer: He thought he was cut off; God heard his supplications
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:22 recounts the psalmist’s fear of being cut off, yet God 'heard the voice of my supplications.' This reflects divine faithfulness in crisis, consistent with Psalm 34:15, Isaiah 41:13, Romans 8:26, and Hebrews 4:16.

questions.question: According to Psalms 31:23, what does the LORD do for the faithful and the proud doer?
options: Preserves the faithful and rewards the proud doer
Punishes the faithful and rewards the proud doer
Preserves the proud and punishes the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: Preserves the faithful and rewards the proud doer
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:23 states, 'the LORD preserveth the faithful, and plentifully rewardeth the proud doer.' The term 'proud doer' here refers to the arrogant evildoer. This theme of divine justice is evident in Psalm 37:28, Proverbs 11:31, Matthew 5:45, and Revelation 22:12, affirming God's judgment and preservation.

questions.question: What encouragement is given in Psalms 31:24 for those who hope in the LORD?
options: Be of good courage; He shall strengthen your heart
questions.correctAnswer: Be of good courage; He shall strengthen your heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 31:24 encourages, 'Be of good courage...all ye that hope in the LORD,' promising strength and heart renewal. This encouragement is echoed in Joshua 1:9, Isaiah 40:31, Romans 15:13, and Philippians 4:13, emphasizing God’s empowering grace.
